div.p:
In con≈øidering the fir≈øt que≈øtion we mu≈øt examine the nature of the air we breath, or atmo≈øpheric air, and the operation breathing effectuates on the animal machine. By the a≈ø≈øiduous application, and unremitted attention of ≈øeveral eminent philo≈øophers and chemi≈øts, among whom the names of Hales, Black, Macbride, Prie≈øtly, Cavendi≈øh, Lavoi≈øeir, Foureroy, Berthollet, Chaptal and De Morveau will not be forgotten while ≈øcience is recorded. We are now able to analy≈øe the atmo≈øpheric air, which in≈øtead of being a ≈øimple element, is found to be a chemical
compound, a knowledge of who≈øe principles becomes the more intere≈øting, as nature has made them her principal agents in mo≈øt of her operations; which may be con≈øidered as her grand laboratory, from which the ≈øeeds and pabulum of animal and vegetable life are derived, and to which their ≈øub≈øequent decompo≈øition returns the ≈øame principles which before were extracted. The phy≈øical properties of atmo≈øpherical air are fluidity, invi≈øibility, gravity, ela≈øticity, compre≈ø≈øibility, and negation of ≈ømell. though foetid and odorant ≈øub≈øtances ≈øometimes affect our organs, they are to be attributed to the extraneous bodies mixed and floating in the air, which is it≈øelf perfectly inodorous.

From the mo≈øt conclu≈øive and ≈øatisfactory experiments of Prie≈øtly and Lavoi≈øier, it is a≈øcertained, that the atmo≈øpheric air will not, in its totality, maintain animal life, or promote combu≈øtion; the proportion of air that an≈øwers either of the≈øe purpo≈øes, compared with the atmo≈øpherical air, is only as 28 is to 100, which has been called by the French academicians oxigenous gas, or oxigen; the re≈øidue, or 72-100 of the atmo≈øpherical air has been called azote, or nitrogene. Mr. Lavoi≈øier's experiments make the atmo≈øpheric air to be compo≈øed of 72 parts of azote, 27 parts of oxigen, and one of carbonic acid, or fixed air.

It has become nece≈ø≈øary, that a revolution in the ≈øcience of chemi≈øtry ≈øhould be attended with a ≈øimilar revolution in its language; for it is impo≈ø≈øible to retain a vicious nomenclature when the ≈øcience becomes enlightened, extended, and ≈øimplified: the words u≈øed ≈øhould always identify the fact, that the knowledge of the one ≈øhould always lead to a knowledge of the other. I am ≈øorry here to be obliged to criticize on ≈øome of the words that have been adopted, becau≈øe they do not carry the unequivocal appropriate ideas which we have
a right to expect, when an innovation is introduced: the word oxigen is derived from the greek, and ≈øignifies the begetter of acid, or the ba≈øis of acidity; ≈øo far the word perfectly corre≈øponds with the fact, and probably it is from this principle only, that it is of ≈øuch infinite and indi≈øpen≈øable importance to animal life: but as it is the e≈ø≈øence of life, this circum≈øtance gives it a priority of claim to ≈øtand its God-father; I ≈øhall therefore ≈øub≈øtitute for it the term animal vital air; this indeed does not de≈øignate all its qualities, nor is it nece≈ø≈øary that it ≈øhould; but it defines, with ≈øufficient correctne≈øs, its great leading trait‚Äîthe ≈øupporter of animal life: the words azote, or nitrogene, are more exceptionable than oxigen; azote is likewi≈øe derived from the Greek, and ≈øignifies without life, which is ju≈øt as de≈øcriptive of the halter or the guillotine, as air: nitrogene is likewi≈øe of Grecian origin, and is meant to ≈øhew, that it is the ba≈øis of nitre; that it is ≈øo, I readily admit, but I am not di≈øpo≈øed to believe, that this trifling circum≈øtance was of ≈øufficient con≈øequence to give a name to the ≈øine qua non of vegetable life; I think it ought rather to have been called vegetable vital air‚Äîa name which I ≈øhall take the liberty to adopt; for it is a fact as well a≈øcertained, as it is po≈ø≈øible for a chemical fact to be, that in this air plants live and vegetate, without it they die: animal vital air is more ponderous than atmo≈øpheric air, as 1000 is to 1103; vegetable vital air, on the contrary, is lighter, as 985 is to 1000; the≈øe two airs, in the proportion of 28 of the former to 72 of the latter, forms the atmo≈øpherical air, which is a chemical compound, and is about 850 times lighter than water.

It is an axiom in chemi≈øtry, that all ≈øub≈øtances in nature, whether in a ≈øimple or compound ≈øtate, would invariably continue in that ≈øame ≈øtate, unle≈øs for a principle which pervades all creation, and is called electric attraction, or affinity of compo≈øition: unions formed from this cau≈øe, are more or le≈øs perfect, in proportion
as their ≈øub≈øtances have a greater or le≈øs affinity for each other. I ≈øhall exemplify my meaning by a ≈øub≈øtance with which we are mo≈øt of us acquainted, to wit, nitre, or ≈øaltpetre100 parts or pounds of nitre are compo≈øed of 30 pounds of nitric acid; 63 pounds of pota≈øh, and 7 pounds of water, which chri≈øtalizes it. , which is compounded of nitric acid The nitric acid is formed of 3 parts of vegetable vital air, and 7 parts of animal vital air, which was di≈øcovered by a very fine experiment made by Mr. Cavendi≈øh. , or what is commonly called aqua fortis, and pota≈øh: now it has been di≈øcovered that the ≈øulphuric acid, or as it is commonly called, oil of vitriol, has a greater affinity for pota≈øh than the nitric acid has; con≈øequently, by placing the≈øe ≈øub≈øtances in a certain temperature together, a decompo≈øition of the nitre takes place‚Äîthe nitric acid is di≈øcharged, and a new union between the pota≈øh and ≈øulphuric acid is formed, which is called the ≈øulphat of pota≈øh. Nitre may likewi≈øe be decompo≈øed in another way: it is known that Barytes, or the Terra Pondero≈øa, has a greater affinity for the nitric acid than what pota≈øh has‚Äîlet them therefore be placed conveniently together, and a decompo≈øition of the nitric is produced, the nitrate of Barytes is formed, and the pota≈øh ≈øet at liberty.

On this principle, when any portion of atmo≈øpheric air comes in contact with any ≈øub≈øtance that has a greater affinity with either of its component parts, than the≈øe parts have for each other, a decompo≈øition of this portion takes place, and a new union is formed.

It is a primordial and invariable law of nature, that all and every part of creation, as well animate as inanimate, ≈øhould be in a con≈øtant ≈øtate of renovation, thro' a continual circulation of decompo≈øitions, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øive generations. The wonderful di≈øcoveries of the chemi≈øts
point out to us in the mo≈øt po≈øitive manner, that the ab≈øolute exi≈øtence of animals and vegetables depends on a mutual reciprocity of each others wants; animals ab≈øorb animal vital air, and emit vegetable vital air; on the contrary, vegetables ab≈øorb vegetable vital air, and emit animal vital air; the leaves are the medium through which this exchange is made by plants; the lungs and the excretory pores, on the ≈øurface of the body, are de≈øtined to this purpo≈øe in animals‚Äîor, in other words, vegetables, when in a ≈øtate of active exi≈øtence, have a greater affinity for vegetable vital air, than what animal vital air has, con≈øequently the vegetable vital air of that part of the atmo≈øpheric air which comes in contact with vegetables in a ≈øtate of verdure, quits its connection with the animal vital air, and attaches it≈øelf to the plant; on the contrary, the animal vital air of the atmo≈øphere has a greater affinity for the blood of animals than it has for vegetable vital air; whenever, therefore, it comes in clo≈øe or near contact with this ≈øub≈øtance, a new union is formed: it is, however, not to be under≈øtood as forming an union with the blood on the ≈øame principles as the ≈øulphuric acid does with the pota≈øh, previou≈øly combined with the nitric acid, becau≈øe, in this ca≈øe, a violent efferve≈øcence takes place, in di≈ølodging the nitric acid, but this union may be more aptly compared to that which takes place between quick lime and fixed air, or carbonic acid, for two rea≈øons‚Äîin the fir≈øt place, the heat that is generated in the lime from this union, is perfectly ≈øimilar to the heat of animals, which is acquired by the ab≈øorption and conden≈øation of animal vital air Mr. Chaptal ob≈øerves, that re≈øpiration may be con≈øidered as an operation, by means of which, vital air po≈ø≈øes continually from the ga≈øeous to the concrete ≈øtate; it mu≈øt, therefore, at each in≈øtant, abandon the heat that held it in ≈øolution, and in the ≈øtate of gas. This heat produced at every in≈øpiration, mu≈øt be proportioned to the volume of the lungs, to the activity of this organ, to the purity of the air, the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of the in≈øpirations, &c. &c. : in the ≈øecond place, the lime is
more or le≈øs acrid in proportion as it is le≈øs or more ≈øaturated with its appropriate acid: on the ≈øame principles the blood of a living animal is le≈øs or more acrid, or fit for the purpo≈øes of life, as it is le≈øs or more neutralized with animal vital air, which is the ba≈øis of acidity; the blood it≈øelf can never ≈øhew any great degree of acridity or corro≈øivene≈øs, becau≈øe it would de≈øtroy animal life before it arrives at this ≈øtate; but that the ≈øecretions from the blood may, and ≈øometimes do become very con≈øiderably acrid, is mo≈øt certain‚Äîparticularly the bile which is always eminently affected in all the di≈øea≈øes in que≈øtion; the bile, in its healthy ≈øtate, is very con≈øiderably alkaline, although ≈øecreted from blood perfectly neutralized‚Äîat lea≈øt, as much as venous blood can be, for the bile is not ≈øecreted from artereal blood; but when the blood is not, from a deficiency of animal vital air, ≈øufficiently neutralized, it is in this ca≈øe ea≈øy to conceive that the bile ≈øecreted from ≈øuch blood will be in exce≈øs, and mu≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈øs a quality verging towards an acrid ≈øtate‚Äîwhich, according to the deficiency of animal vital air, and the heat of the ≈øea≈øon, as we ≈øhall by and by ≈øee, may produce a di≈øea≈øe of ≈ølight affection only‚Äîas the fever and ague, or of the mo≈øt virulent kind, the plague it≈øelf.

Every animal is furni≈øhed with lungs, or ≈øomething corre≈øponding thereto, through which the blood in con≈øtant ≈øucce≈ø≈øion pa≈ø≈øes, by which means it is brought in clo≈øe contact with the atmo≈øpheric air, and from which we now know it ab≈øorbs that part of it which we call animal vital air; after the atmo≈øpheric air has thus been re≈øpired, it lo≈øes its property of ≈øupporting the lives of other animals: when an animal has died in this re≈øpired air, and another is ≈øub≈øtituted to the fir≈øt, it peri≈øhes in≈øtantly, and in its fir≈øt effort to re≈øpire: it ≈øhould ≈øeem, however, that animals may, by habit, become capable, to a certain point, of breathing impure air.

The phoenomena of re≈øpiration are but lately a≈øcertained
though from the time of Hippocrates it has been admitted, that in the air re≈øides a principle nece≈ø≈øary to life, which by him was called the pabulum vitae; this idea was connected with no hypothe≈øis; ≈øy≈øtems the mo≈øt vague and void of all foundations, have at different times been held up; at one time con≈øidering the air as a ≈øtimulus in the lungs, which kept up the circulation; at another the lungs were con≈øidered as a bellows to cool the body, heated by a thou≈øand imaginary cau≈øes. Phy≈øiologi≈øts of the pre≈øent day ≈øeem to con≈øider them as the outlets of certain putrid effluviae, which would corrupt the living body in the ≈øame manner that it produces corruption in tho≈øe that are dead. The rationale is extremely again≈øt ≈øuch a theory; for is it conceiveable that the ≈øame vi≈øeus can be at the ≈øame moment performing two functions diametrically oppo≈øite to each other? that of ab≈øorbing and ≈øecreting through the ≈øame ve≈ø≈øels, unle≈øs they ≈øuppo≈øe it ≈øimilar to elective attraction, as mentioned before, where pota≈øh having a greater affinity for the ≈øulphuric acid than for the nitric acid, di≈øcharges this acid with which it was previou≈øly combined. But there is no ≈øort of analogy in this ca≈øe, for the matter di≈øcharged from the lungs in≈øtead of being an acid, is more of an alkaline nature, mixed with carbon; which I think is very ≈øufficiently accounted for, on the following principles: In examining the con≈øtruction of lungs, we find them furni≈øhed with two ≈øetts of ve≈ø≈øels, a larger and a ≈ømaller; through the larger the whole of the blood of the ≈øy≈øtem is con≈øtantly tran≈ømitted, for the exclu≈øive purpo≈øe of attracting animal vital air from the atmo≈øphere. The ≈ømaller ≈øett is appropriated to the exclu≈øive ≈øupport of the lungs them≈øelves, and to furni≈øh a con≈øiderable ≈øecretion, nece≈ø≈øary to lubricate a part which is in ≈øuch con≈øtant motion, to facilitate the return of the re≈øpired air in the atmo≈øphere; and to „Äà‚óä„Äâ the acrimony of any heterogeneous matter with which the atmo≈øphere is frequently charged. This ≈øecretion will ≈øufficiently account for the great quantity of moi≈øture di≈øcharged in expiration. The excretory pores di≈øtributed over the whole ≈øurface of the body are
≈øufficiently competent to di≈øcharge this duty which has been a≈ø≈øigned to the lungs by our modern phy≈øiologi≈øts.

It has been long an e≈øtabli≈øhed principle among phy≈øicians, that all animals have a con≈øtant tendency to putrefaction; but it has been re≈øerved for our own times, to point out the cau≈øe that is capable of correcting this tendency. Borehave in his aphori≈øms, ¬ß. 83, ≈øays, in≈øects, fi≈øhes, amphibious creatures, birds, bea≈øts of all kinds, and even men of their own nature, con≈øtantly incline to putrefaction, but never turn acid Van Sweten in his commentaries on this aphori≈øm ≈øays, all the known animals (except a few juicele≈øs in≈øects, for moi≈øture is required in putrefaction, and the parts of animals never putrefy if they are dried) putrefy, if expo≈øed to the heat of an air, which ≈øhall cau≈øe the liquid to ri≈øe in the Farenheitian thermometer to any degree between the 32d and the 92d. The greater the heat is within this limit, ≈øo much the ≈øooner for the mo≈øt part will the putrefaction begin, for beyond the 92d degree the heat rather drys up all moi≈øture, and ≈øo hinders putrefaction, and the nearer the de≈øcending heat approaches to a like degree of coldne≈øs with that of ice, the ≈ølower the putrefaction comes on. In fi≈øhes it generally comes on very ≈øoon, more ≈ølowly in other animals. Nor does it appear by any experiment, that the parts of animals have ever degenerated of them≈øelves into an acid; this therefore may be taken for a general rule. It appears therefore, that one of the great charactari≈øtic differences between the animal and vegetable kingdoms, is this, that animals con≈øtantly tend to an alkaline or putre≈øcent ≈øtate, and vegetables to that of acidity. We have ≈øeen before that the two kingdoms are con≈øtantly mutually correcting each others morbid tendency, through the medium of the atmo≈øphere.

From the≈øe premi≈øes it is ea≈øy to conceive, that when the atmo≈øpherical air in any particular place, is not from any cau≈øe ≈øufficiently replete with animal vital air, this
